p.text: Without prejudice to the right of appeal conferred by subsection (2) , the Court shall not have jurisdiction to set aside or remit an award on the ground of error of fact or law on the face of the award.
Subject to subsection (4) , an appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court on any question of law arising out of an award.
On the determination of an appeal under subsection (2) the Supreme Court may by order—
confirm, vary or set aside the award; or

remit the award, together with the Supreme Court's opinion on the question of law which was the subject of the appeal, to the arbitrator or umpire for reconsideration or, where a new arbitrator or umpire has been appointed, to that arbitrator or umpire for consideration,
and where the award is remitted under paragraph (b) the arbitrator or umpire shall, unless the order otherwise directs, make the award within 3 months after the date of the order.
An appeal under subsection (2) may be brought by any of the parties to an arbitration agreement—
with the consent of all the other parties to the arbitration agreement; or
subject to section 40 , with the leave of the Supreme Court.
[subs (4) am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
The Supreme Court shall not grant leave under subsection (4)(b) unless it considers that:
having regard to all the circumstances, the determination of the question of law concerned could substantially affect the rights of one or more parties to the arbitration agreement; and
there is:
a manifest error of law on the face of the award; or
strong evidence that the arbitrator or umpire made an error of law and that the determination of the question may add, or may be likely to add, substantially to the certainty of commercial law.
[subs (5) subst Act 100 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1]
The Supreme Court may make any leave which it grants under subsection (4)(b) subject to the applicant complying with any conditions it considers appropriate.
[subs (6) subst Act 100 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1]

Where the award of an arbitrator or umpire is varied on an appeal under subsection (2) , the award as varied shall have effect (except for the purposes of this section) as if it were the award of the arbitrator or umpire.
[subs (7) insrt Act 100 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1]
Legislation cited in [275,325.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 s 38(5), s 38(5)(b)(i).

Section 38(5) , which was amended in 1990, was designed to restrict the scope for judicial supervision of arbitral awards. The decision to grant leave to appeal does not involve the exercise of a broad discretion having regard to all the circumstances of the case: cf Qantas Airways Ltd v Joseland & Gilling (1986) 6 NSWLR 327 . Rather, s 38(5) requires that a strong and compelling argument is necessary before leave will be granted. The court will not permit leave applications to be treated as if they were appeals: New South Wales v Coya (Constructions) Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Full Court, 4 August 1995, unreported, BC9505126) . The requirement, imposed by s 38(5)(b)(i) , that there be "manifest error of law on the face of the award" means that the error must be "evident" or "obvious" rather than simply "arguable". "Prolonged adversarial argument" should not be necessary: Promenade Investments Pty Ltd v New South Wales (1992) 26 NSWLR 203 ; Natoli v Walker (NSWCA, Full Court, 26 May 1994, unreported, BC9402554) . The extent to which a judge should entertain argument on an application for leave to appeal will depend upon the number of asserted errors and, in respect of each, the relative complexity of each error. Generally, an error is unlikely to be “manifest” if competent counsel has not disclosed it within approximately half an hour: Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd v Commonwealth (NSWSC, Bainton J, No 50256/96, 29 May 1996, unreported, BC9602289) .

A submission that there is no evidence to support a finding of fact by an arbitrator is not a question of law arising out of the award. Evidence that has been referred to in the award can be examined in order to understand the award itself or the reasons for making the award. Wavley Pty Ltd v Adco Constructions Pty Ltd (1988) 5 BCL 141 ; Stavropoulos v Kordas & Lucas Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Brownie J, 22 May 1989, unreported, BC8902149) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,330] s 39 Determination of preliminary point of law by Supreme Court

leg:heading.title: Determination of preliminary point of law by Supreme Court

p.text: Subject to subsection (2) and section 40 , on an application to the Supreme Court made by any of the parties to an arbitration agreement—
with the consent of an arbitrator who has entered on the reference or, if an umpire has entered on the reference, with the consent of the umpire; or
with the consent of all the other parties,
the Supreme Court shall have jurisdiction to determine any question of law arising in the course of the arbitration.
The Supreme Court shall not entertain an application under subsection (1)(a) with respect to any question of law unless it is satisfied that—
the determination of the application might produce substantial savings in costs to the parties; and
the question of law is one in respect of which leave to appeal would be likely to be granted under section 38(4)(b) .
Legislation cited in [275,330.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 s 39, s 44.

The court generally has no inherent power to intervene in interlocutory orders of an arbitrator except in the determination of a preliminary point of law under s 39 or in proceedings under s 44 of the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 for the removal of the arbitrator: Imperial Leatherware Co Pty Ltd v Macri & Marcellino Pty Ltd (1991) 22 NSWLR 653 ; Commonwealth v Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd (1995) 36 NSWLR 662; 120 FLR 171; BC9504837 ; Nauru Phosphate Royalties Trust v Matthew Hall Mechanical and Electrical Engineers Pty Ltd [1994] 2 VR 386 . However, in an exceptional case where the arbitrator's orders go outside the legitimate scope of the arbitration, the court may intervene: Commonwealth v Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd , above (confidentiality orders restraining the Commonwealth from releasing documents of potential public importance).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,335] s 40 Exclusion agreements affecting rights under sections 38 and 39

leg:heading.title: Exclusion agreements affecting rights under sections 38 and 39

p.text: Subject to this section and section 41 —
the Supreme Court shall not, under section 38(4)(b) , grant leave to appeal with respect to a question of law arising out of an award; and
no application may be made under section 39(1)(a) with respect to a question of law,

if there is in force an agreement in writing (in this section and section 41 referred to as an exclusion agreement ) between the parties to the arbitration agreement which excludes the right of appeal under section 38(2) in relation to the award or, in a case falling within paragraph (b) , in relation to an award to which the determination of the question of law is material.
[subs (1) am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]

An exclusion agreement may be expressed so as to relate to a particular award, to awards under a particular arbitration agreement or to any other description of awards, whether arising out of the same arbitration agreement or not.

An agreement may be an exclusion agreement for the purposes of this section whether it is entered into before or after the commencement of this Act and whether or not it forms part of an arbitration agreement.
Except as provided by subsection (1) , sections 38 and 39 shall have effect notwithstanding anything in any agreement purporting—
to prohibit or restrict access to the Supreme Court; or
to restrict the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
An exclusion agreement shall be of no effect in relation to an award made on, or a question of law arising in the course of, an arbitration being an arbitration under any other Act.

An exclusion agreement shall be of no effect in relation to an award made on, or a question of law arising in the course of, an arbitration under an arbitration agreement which is a domestic arbitration agreement unless the exclusion agreement is entered into after the commencement of the arbitration in which the award is made or, as the case requires, in which the question of law arises.

In this section, domestic arbitration agreement means an arbitration agreement which does not provide, expressly or by implication, for arbitration in a country other than Australia and to which neither—
an individual who is a national of, or habitually resident in, any country other than Australia; nor
a body corporate which is incorporated in, or whose central management and control is exercised in, any country other than Australia,
is a party at the time the arbitration agreement is entered into.
Legislation cited in [275,335.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 s 41.

Agreements under which athletes and officials submit to the jurisdiction of the Court of Arbitration for Sport, if they provide for a foreign "seat" of arbitration, will usually constitute an effective exclusion agreement for the purposes of s 41 of the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984: Raguz v Sullivan (2000) 50 NSWLR 236; [2000] NSWCA 240; BC200005206 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,340] s 41 Exclusion agreements not to apply in certain cases

leg:heading.title: Exclusion agreements not to apply in certain cases

p.text: Subject to subsection (3) , if an award or a question of law arising in the course of an arbitration relates, in whole or in part, to—
a question or claim falling within the Admiralty jurisdiction of the Supreme Court;
a dispute arising out of a contract of insurance; or
a dispute arising out of a commodity contract,
an exclusion agreement shall have no effect in relation to the award or question unless either—
the exclusion agreement is entered into after the commencement of the arbitration in which the award is made or, as the case requires, in which the question of law arises; or
the award or question relates to a contract which is expressed to be governed by a law other than the law of New South Wales.
In subsection (1)(c) , "commodity contract" means a contract—
for the sale of goods regularly dealt with on a commodity market or exchange in New South Wales which is specified for the purposes of this section by a regulation made by the Governor; and
of a description specified for the purposes of this section by a regulation made by the Governor.
The Governor may by regulation provide that subsection (1) —
shall cease to have effect; or
subject to such conditions as may be specified in the regulation, shall not apply to any exclusion agreement made in relation to an award of a description specified in the regulation,
and a regulation made under this subsection may contain such supplementary, incidental and transitional provisions as appear to the Governor to be necessary.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,345] s 42 Power to set aside award

p.text: Where—
there has been misconduct on the part of an arbitrator or umpire or an arbitrator or umpire has misconducted the proceedings; or
the arbitration or award has been improperly procured,
the Court may, on the application of a party to the arbitration agreement, set the award aside either wholly or in part.

Where the arbitrator or umpire has misconducted the proceedings by making an award partly in respect of a matter not referred to arbitration pursuant to the arbitration agreement, the Court may set aside that part of the award if it can do so without materially affecting the remaining part of the award.

Where an application is made under this section to set aside an award, the Court may order that any money made payable by the award shall be paid into court or otherwise secured pending the determination of the application.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,350] s 43 Court may remit matter for reconsideration

leg:heading.title: Court may remit matter for reconsideration

p.text: Subject to section 38(1) , the Court may remit any matter referred to arbitration by an arbitration agreement together with any directions it thinks proper to the arbitrator or umpire for reconsideration or, where a new arbitrator or umpire has been appointed, to that arbitrator or umpire for consideration.
Legislation cited in [275,350.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 s 43.

Where an arbitrator provides inadequate reasons for his or her award, the court may exercise the power under s 43 to obtain supplementary reasons or clarification of the award: Sabemo Pty Ltd v Malaysia Hotel (Aust) Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Giles J, No 55007/92, 4 June 1992, unreported, BC9201836) .
As to the extent of the obligation to give reasons, see [40.2.2] .

A matter may be remitted to the arbitrator on ground of discovery of fresh evidence after publication of an award. The test for fresh evidence in the context of arbitral proceedings is the same as that for the grant of a new trial: Hashman v Downie (1996) 39 NSWLR 169 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,355] s 44 Removal of arbitrator or umpire

p.text: Where the Court is satisfied that—
there has been misconduct on the part of an arbitrator or umpire or an arbitrator or umpire has misconducted the proceedings;
undue influence has been exercised in relation to an arbitrator or umpire; or
an arbitrator or umpire is incompetent or unsuitable to deal with the particular dispute,
the Court may, on the application of a party to the arbitration agreement, remove the arbitrator or umpire.

The words of the section indicate that it has a wider ambit than merely personal misconduct of the arbitrator. The section is concerned with technical misconduct in connection with the handling of the arbitration. It need not involve misconduct in the popular sense and need not involve any personal turpitude: Doran Constructions Pty Ltd v Health Administration Corp of New South Wales (1994) 12 BCL 59 ; London Export Corp Ltd v Jubilee Coffee Roasting Co Ltd [1958] 1 WLR 661 ; Williams v Wallis [1914] 2 KB 478 at 485 ; Gas & Fuel Corp of Victoria v Wood Hall Ltd [1978] VR 385 at 391 . If misconduct is established removal of the arbitrator is the exclusive remedy provided by the section. There is no power to remit the proceedings back to the arbitrator with directions as to its future conduct: Bremer Vulkan Schiffbau und Maschinenfabrik v South India Shipping Corp Ltd [1981] AC 909 at 938, 987, 997 ; Biakh & Biali v Hyundai Corp Ltd [1988] 1 Lloyds Rep 187 .
Legislation cited in [275,355.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 s 44(c).

An arbitrator will not necessarily be unsuitable within the meaning of s 44(c) in circumstances where that arbitrator had previously acted both as arbitrator and counsel in two earlier arbitrations involving broadly similar issues and witnesses who were also to give evidence in the arbitration: Gascor (t/as Gas and Fuel) v Ellicott [1997] 1 VR 332 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,360] s 45 Party not prevented from alleging that arbitrator appointed by that party is not impartial, suitable or competent

leg:heading.title: Party not prevented from alleging that arbitrator appointed by that party is not impartial, suitable or competent

p.text: A party to an arbitration agreement is not prevented from alleging in any legal proceedings with respect to the agreement that an arbitrator is not or may not be impartial, suitable or competent by reason of a power of appointment having been exercised by that party in relation to the appointment of that arbitrator or by reason of facts or circumstances that that party knew or ought to have known when exercising that power.
For the purposes of this section, where an arbitrator is named or designated in an arbitration agreement, a party to the agreement shall be deemed—
to have exercised a power of appointment in relation to the appointment of that arbitrator; and
to have exercised that power at the time when the party entered into the arbitration agreement.

Unless a contrary intention is expressed in the arbitration agreement, it is an implied term of the agreement that in the event of a dispute arising to which the agreement applies it is the duty of each party to the agreement to exercise due diligence in the taking of steps that are necessary to have the dispute referred to arbitration and dealt with in arbitration proceedings.
Where there has been undue delay by a party, the Court may, on the application of any other party to the dispute or an arbitrator or umpire, make orders:
terminating the arbitration proceedings;
removing the dispute into Court; and
dealing with any incidental matters.
The Court shall not make an order under subsection (2) unless it is satisfied that the delay:
has been inordinate and inexcusable; and

will give rise to a substantial risk of it not being possible to have a fair trial of the issues in the arbitration proceedings or is such as is likely to cause or to have caused serious prejudice to the other parties to the arbitration proceedings.
[s 46 subst Act 100 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,370] s 47 General power of the Court to make interlocutory orders

leg:heading.title: General power of the Court to make interlocutory orders

p.text: The Court shall have the same power of making interlocutory orders for the purposes of and in relation to arbitration proceedings as it has for the purposes of and in relation to proceedings in the Court.

This section does not authorise the Supreme Court to entertain appeals from interlocutory orders made by an arbitrator: Imperial Leatherware Co Pty Ltd v Macri & Marcellino Pty Ltd (1991) 22 NSWLR 653 ; Commonwealth v Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd (1995) 36 NSWLR 662; 120 FLR 171; BC9504837 ; contrast Aerospatiale Holdings Australia Pty Ltd v Elspan International Ltd (1992) 28 NSWLR 321 .

Subject to subsection (3) , the Court shall have power on the application of a party to an arbitration agreement or an arbitrator or umpire to extend the time appointed by or under this Act or fixed by the agreement or by an order under this section for doing any act or taking any proceeding in or in relation to an arbitration.

The Court may make an order under this section although an application for the making of the order was not made until after the expiration of the time appointed or fixed for doing the act or taking the proceeding.
An order shall not be made under this section extending the time within which arbitration proceedings might be commenced unless—
the Court is satisfied that in the circumstances of the case undue hardship would otherwise be caused; and
the making of the order would not contravene the provision of any enactment limiting the time for the commencement of arbitration proceedings.

The words "in or in relation to" in s 48(1) are wide and extend to the taking of a step which is a condition precedent to arbitration, even where there is a right to elect between proceeding in the courts and proceeding by way of arbitration: PMT Partners Pty Ltd (in liq) v Australian National Parks & Wildlife Service (1995) 184 CLR 301; 131 ALR 377 . Where the parties have agreed that a matter is to proceed to arbitration the court should give effect to the parties' intent by granting an extension of time unless the factors in s 48(3) are present: Alto Constructions Pty Ltd v University of New South Wales (NSWSC, Young J, 2549/95, 15 December 1995, unreported, BC9506807) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,380] s 49 Power to impose terms on orders, etc

leg:heading.title: Power to impose terms on orders, etc

p.text: Subject to this Act, an order, direction or decision made under this Act by the Supreme Court or the District Court may be made on such terms and conditions (including terms and conditions as to costs) as the Supreme Court or the District Court thinks just.
